title: AI-Driven Drug Discovery: A Hands-On Guide
text:
Preface
This is a Quarto book.
To learn more about Quarto books visit https://quarto.org/docs/books.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
This is a book created from markdown and executable code.
See Knuth (1984) for additional discussion of literate programming.




Knuth, Donald E. 1984. “Literate Programming.” Comput. J. 27 (2): 97–111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.

title: 2  Summary
text: In summary, this book has no content whatsoever.

title: References
text:
Knuth, Donald E. 1984. “Literate Programming.” Comput.
J. 27 (2): 97–111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.

title: 1  Preface
text:
2 Preface
Welcome to “AI-Driven Drug Discovery: A Hands-On Guide.” This book is designed for data scientists, bioinformaticians, and machine learning engineers who want to apply their skills to the world of drug discovery. Our goal is to provide a practical, code-first approach to modern computational drug discovery, with real-world examples and hands-on exercises throughout.
We hope this book empowers you to make meaningful contributions to the future of medicine.

title: 2  Introduction
text:
3 Introduction
Artificial intelligence is revolutionizing drug discovery. This book introduces the key concepts, tools, and workflows that are shaping the future of pharmaceutical research. You will learn how to leverage AI, machine learning, and public biomedical data to accelerate the discovery of new medicines.
We begin with foundational concepts and build up to advanced, real-world applications, ensuring you gain both theoretical understanding and practical skills.

title: 3  Chapter 1: Genomics to Molecules
text:
3.1 Summary
This chapter introduces the journey from genomics data to actionable molecular targets in drug discovery. It covers how genetic information is translated into protein targets and how these are linked to small molecules for therapeutic intervention.
This workflow demonstrates how to start from a gene (e.g., SOD1 for ALS), find the corresponding protein (UniProt), retrieve known small-molecule ligands (ChEMBL), and analyze their molecular properties. This bridges genomics and cheminformatics, enabling rational drug discovery starting from genetic information.

title: 3  Genomics to Molecules
text:
4.1 Learning Objectives

Understand how to bridge genomics (genes/proteins) and cheminformatics (small molecules) in drug discovery
Use public databases and Python tools to go from gene to protein to ligand
Analyze molecular properties of drug-like compounds

title: 3  Genomics to Molecules
text:
4.2 Introduction
Modern drug discovery often starts with genomics—identifying disease-relevant genes and proteins. The next step is to find or design small molecules that can modulate these targets. This chapter demonstrates a practical, stepwise workflow: from gene to protein to ligand to molecular property analysis, using real-world data and open-source tools.

title: 3  Genomics to Molecules
text:
4.3 Core Concepts

Genomics pipelines vs. drug discovery workflows
The role of AI in modern pharma (AlphaFold, DeepMind, etc.)
Overview of AI-discovered drugs in clinical trials
Setting up your development environment (Python, Jupyter, RDKit, etc.)

title: 3  Genomics to Molecules
text:
4.4 Hands-On Implementation
# Install RDKit and other essentials
!pip install rdkit-pypi pandas

from rdkit import Chem
from rdkit.Chem import Descriptors
import pandas as pd

# Example: Load a SMILES string and calculate properties
smiles = "CC(=O)OC1=CC=CC=C1C(=O)O"  # Aspirin
mol = Chem.MolFromSmiles(smiles)

if mol:
    mw = Descriptors.MolWt(mol)
    logp = Descriptors.MolLogP(mol)
    print(f"Molecular Weight: {mw:.2f}")
    print(f"LogP: {logp:.2f}")
else:
    print("Invalid SMILES string.")

title: 3  Genomics to Molecules
text:
4.5 Case Study / Real-World Example
AlphaFold’s protein structure predictions have enabled rapid target identification for diseases. For example, researchers can now model protein-ligand interactions for novel targets in Alzheimer’s disease, accelerating the path from genomics data to candidate molecules.

title: 3  Genomics to Molecules
text:
4.6 Common Challenges & Solutions

Data integration between genomics and cheminformatics
Handling large datasets and computational resources
Ensuring reproducibility in research workflows

text:

Analyze the properties of several ligands and compare their drug-likeness
Research a real-world example where genomics led to a new drug discovery

title: 4  Target Identification
text:
5.1 Learning Objectives

Explain the importance of target identification in drug discovery
Use AI and NLP tools to mine biomedical literature for targets
Access and analyze public databases (e.g., UniProt, PubMed)
Implement a basic target mining workflow in Python
Evaluate the quality and druggability of identified targets

title: 4  Target Identification
text:
5.2 Introduction
Target identification is the first critical step in the drug discovery pipeline. Advances in AI and natural language processing (NLP) have made it possible to mine vast biomedical literature and databases to uncover novel drug targets efficiently.

title: 4  Target Identification
text:
5.3 Core Concepts

What makes a good drug target?
Data sources: UniProt, PubMed, Open Targets
AI/NLP for literature mining (e.g., BioBERT, PubMedBERT)
Target validation and prioritization

title: 4  Target Identification
text:
5.4 Hands-On Implementation
# Install transformers and biopython
!pip install transformers biopython

from transformers import pipeline
from Bio import Entrez

# Example: Use Hugging Face pipeline for NER on biomedical text
nlp = pipeline("ner", model="d4data/biobert-ner")
text = "APP and BACE1 are key targets in Alzheimer's disease."
results = nlp(text)
print(results)

# Example: Search PubMed for Alzheimer's targets
Entrez.email = "your.email@example.com"
handle = Entrez.esearch(db="pubmed", term="Alzheimer target", retmax=5)
record = Entrez.read(handle)
print("PubMed IDs:", record["IdList"])

title: 5  Part I: Foundations
text:
6 Part I: Foundations
This part introduces the essential concepts and tools for AI-driven drug discovery, including cheminformatics, molecular representations, and compound screening.

title: 6  Cheminformatics Essentials
text:
7.1 Learning Objectives

Understand molecular representations (SMILES, InChI, graphs)
Calculate key molecular properties
Apply Lipinski’s Rule of Five for drug-likeness
Use RDKit for molecule manipulation and visualization
Build a simple molecular property calculator

title: 6  Cheminformatics Essentials
text:
7.2 Introduction
Cheminformatics is the backbone of computational drug discovery. It enables the digital representation, analysis, and manipulation of molecules, making it possible to apply machine learning and AI to chemical data.

title: 6  Cheminformatics Essentials
text:
7.3 Core Concepts

SMILES, InChI, and molecular graphs
Lipinski’s Rule of Five and drug-likeness
Molecular descriptors and property calculations
Data formats: SDF, CSV, SMILES lists

title: 6  Cheminformatics Essentials
text:
7.4 Hands-On Implementation
# Install RDKit
!pip install rdkit-pypi

from rdkit import Chem
from rdkit.Chem import Descriptors, Draw
from rdkit.Chem.Draw import IPythonConsole
from rdkit.Chem import Crippen

# Example: Calculate properties for a list of molecules
smiles_list = [
    "CCO",  # ethanol
    "CC(=O)OC1=CC=CC=C1C(=O)O",  # aspirin
    "CCN(CC)CCCC(C)NC1=C2C=CC(=CC2=NC=C1)Cl"  # chlorpromazine
]

for smi in smiles_list:
    mol = Chem.MolFromSmiles(smi)
    if mol:
        mw = Descriptors.MolWt(mol)
        logp = Crippen.MolLogP(mol)
        print(f"SMILES: {smi}\tMW: {mw:.2f}\tLogP: {logp:.2f}")
        display(Draw.MolToImage(mol))
    else:
        print(f"Invalid SMILES: {smi}")

text:
8.1 Learning Objectives

title: 7  Compound Screening
text:
8.2 Introduction
Compound screening is a key step in drug discovery, enabling researchers to identify promising molecules from vast chemical libraries. Virtual screening, powered by cheminformatics and AI, accelerates this process and reduces experimental costs.

title: 7  Compound Screening
text:
8.3 Core Concepts

Types of screening: high-throughput, virtual, fragment-based
Public compound databases: PubChem, ChEMBL
Drug-likeness and ADMET (absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion, toxicity)
Filtering and prioritization strategies

title: 7  Compound Screening
text:
8.4 Hands-On Implementation
# Install required libraries
!pip install pubchempy chembl_webresource_client pandas

import pubchempy as pcp
from chembl_webresource_client.new_client import new_client
import pandas as pd

# Example: Search PubChem for aspirin
compounds = pcp.get_compounds('aspirin', 'name')
for c in compounds:
    print(f"CID: {c.cid}, Canonical SMILES: {c.canonical_smiles}")

# Example: Search ChEMBL for approved drugs
molecule = new_client.molecule
approved_drugs = molecule.filter(max_phase=4)
for drug in approved_drugs[:5]:
    print(drug['molecule_chembl_id'], drug['pref_name'])

9  Machine Learning for Drug Discovery

title: 9  Machine Learning for Drug Discovery
text:
10.4 Hands-On Implementation
# Install required libraries
!pip install scikit-learn rdkit-pypi pandas

from rdkit import Chem
from rdkit.Chem import Descriptors
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error

# Example: Predict molecular weight from SMILES (toy example)
data = {'smiles': ['CCO', 'CC(=O)OC1=CC=CC=C1C(=O)O', 'CCN(CC)CCCC(C)NC1=C2C=CC(=CC2=NC=C1)Cl'],
        'property': [46.07, 180.16, 318.86]}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
df['mol'] = df['smiles'].apply(Chem.MolFromSmiles)
df['mw'] = df['mol'].apply(Descriptors.MolWt)

X = df[['mw']]
y = df['property']
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.33, random_state=42)

model = RandomForestRegressor()
model.fit(X_train, y_train)
preds = model.predict(X_test)
print("MSE:", mean_squared_error(y_test, preds))

title: 10  Conclusion
text:
11 Conclusion
You have completed “AI-Driven Drug Discovery: A Hands-On Guide.” We hope you now feel equipped to apply AI and computational tools to real-world drug discovery challenges. Continue exploring, building, and contributing to this exciting field!

title: 3  Genomics to Molecules
section: 4.3 Step 1: Start from a Gene Symbol
text:
4.3 Step 1: Start from a Gene Symbol
We begin with a gene of interest. For example, the APP gene (Amyloid beta precursor protein) is associated with Alzheimer’s disease.

title: 3  Genomics to Molecules
text:
4.4 Step 2: Retrieve the Protein (UniProt)
We use the UniProt database to find the protein corresponding to our gene in humans.
import requests
gene_symbol = 'APP'  # Amyloid beta precursor protein
uniprot_url = f'https://rest.uniprot.org/uniprotkb/search?query=gene_exact:{gene_symbol}+AND+organism_id:9606&fields=accession,protein_name,gene_names,organism_name,length&format=tsv'
resp = requests.get(uniprot_url)
print('UniProt search result:')
print(resp.text)
# Extract UniProt accession
lines = resp.text.strip().split('\n')
if len(lines) > 1:
    acc = lines[1].split('\t')[0]
    print(f'UniProt accession for APP: {acc}')
else:
    acc = None
    print('No UniProt entry found.')

title: 3  Genomics to Molecules
section: 4.5 Step 3: Find Known Ligands for the Target (ChEMBL)
text:
4.5 Step 3: Find Known Ligands for the Target (ChEMBL)
With the UniProt accession, we can search ChEMBL for known ligands (small molecules) that interact with this protein target.
from chembl_webresource_client.new_client import new_client
target = new_client.target
activity = new_client.activity
if acc:
    # Find ChEMBL target for UniProt accession
    targets = target.filter(target_components__accession=acc)
    targets = list(targets)
    if targets:
        chembl_id = targets[0]['target_chembl_id']
        print(f'ChEMBL target ID: {chembl_id}')
        # Find bioactive molecules for this target
        acts = activity.filter(target_chembl_id=chembl_id, standard_type='IC50')
        print('Top 5 ligands with IC50:')
        ligands = []
        for a in list(acts)[:5]:
            mol_id = a.get('molecule_chembl_id', 'NA')
            ic50 = a.get('standard_value', 'NA')
            units = a.get('standard_units', '')
            print(f'Molecule: {mol_id}, IC50: {ic50} {units}')
            ligands.append(mol_id)
    else:
        print('No ChEMBL target found for this UniProt accession.')
else:
    print('No UniProt accession available for ligand search.')

title: 3  Genomics to Molecules
section: 4.6 Step 4: Analyze a Ligand’s Molecular Properties (RDKit)
text:
4.6 Step 4: Analyze a Ligand’s Molecular Properties (RDKit)
Pick a ligand from the previous step (e.g., CHEMBL311039) and analyze its structure and properties.
from chembl_webresource_client.new_client import new_client
from rdkit import Chem
from rdkit.Chem import Descriptors
molecule = new_client.molecule
ligand_chembl_id = 'CHEMBL311039'  # Replace with a ligand from above if desired
mol_data = molecule.get(ligand_chembl_id)
smiles = mol_data.get('molecule_structures', {}).get('canonical_smiles', None)
print(f'Ligand {ligand_chembl_id} SMILES:', smiles)
if smiles:
    mol = Chem.MolFromSmiles(smiles)
    mw = Descriptors.MolWt(mol)
    logp = Descriptors.MolLogP(mol)
    print(f'Molecular Weight: {mw:.2f}')
    print(f'LogP: {logp:.2f}')
else:
    print('No SMILES found for this ligand.')

title: 20  Chapter 16: Multi-Modal Learning
text:
20.1 16.1 What is Multi-Modal Learning?
Multi-modal learning combines data types (e.g., chemical, biological, clinical) for improved predictions. This chapter explores architectures and applications in drug discovery.

title: 4  Chapter 2: Environment Setup
text:
4.1 2.1 Installing Python and Conda
This chapter guides you through setting up a reproducible computational environment for AI-driven drug discovery, including Python, Jupyter, and essential libraries.

title: 6  Chapter 3: Cheminformatics Essentials
text:
6.1 3.1 Molecular Representations (SMILES, InChI)
Cheminformatics is the foundation for representing, searching, and analyzing chemical structures computationally. This chapter covers molecular representations, file formats, and basic cheminformatics operations.

title: 7  Chapter 4: Molecular Fingerprints
text:
7.1 4.1 What Are Molecular Fingerprints?
Molecular fingerprints are compact representations of chemical structures used for similarity searching and machine learning. This chapter explains different types of fingerprints and their applications.

title: 8  Chapter 5: Molecular Properties
text:
8.1 5.1 Physicochemical Descriptors
This chapter explores key physicochemical properties of molecules (e.g., logP, MW, H-bond donors/acceptors) and their importance in drug design and ADMET prediction.

title: 10  Chapter 6: Graph Neural Networks
text:
10.1 Summary
Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) are powerful tools for learning on molecular graphs. This chapter introduces GNN concepts and their application to molecular property prediction, including how molecules are represented as graphs and how GNNs can learn from these structures.
crumbs: Part II: Machine Learning for Molecules

title: 11  Chapter 7: Bioactivity Prediction
text:
11.1 Summary
Predicting the biological activity of molecules is central to drug discovery. This chapter covers data sources, machine learning models, and evaluation strategies for bioactivity prediction, including how to prepare data and assess model performance.

title: 16  Chapter 12: Protein Structure
text:
16.1 12.1 Protein Structure Levels
Understanding protein structure is key to structure-based drug design. This chapter covers protein structure basics, experimental methods, and computational prediction (e.g., AlphaFold).

title: 17  Chapter 13: Molecular Docking
text:
17.1 13.1 Docking Theory
Molecular docking predicts how small molecules bind to protein targets. This chapter introduces docking theory, software, and practical workflows for virtual screening.

title: 18  Chapter 14: ML-Enhanced Docking
text:
18.1 14.1 ML Scoring Functions
Machine learning can improve docking accuracy and speed. This chapter discusses ML scoring functions, pose prediction, and integration with docking pipelines.

title: 19  Chapter 15: Retrosynthesis
text:
19.1 15.1 Introduction to Retrosynthesis
Retrosynthesis planning is essential for proposing synthetic routes to molecules. This chapter covers rule-based and AI-driven retrosynthesis tools and strategies.

title: 3  Chapter 1: Genomics to Molecules
text:
3.2 Key Code Snippets

3.2.1 1. Retrieve ALS Target Genes from Open Targets
import requests
efo_id = "Orphanet_803"  # ALS
ot_url = f"https://platform-api.opentargets.io/v3/platform/public/association/filter?disease={efo_id}&size=30&fields=target.gene_info.symbol,target.gene_info.name,association_score.overall"
resp = requests.get(ot_url)
gene_hits = resp.json().get('data', [])
als_genes = [g['target']['gene_info']['symbol'] for g in gene_hits]
print('Top ALS target genes:', als_genes)


3.2.2 2. Batch Extract Non-Protein Entities from PDB
import requests, pandas as pd
pdb_ids = ['2RSQ', '4RFX', '7WWT', ...]  # your PDB list
all_results = []
for pdb_id in pdb_ids:
    url = f'https://data.rcsb.org/rest/v1/core/entry/{pdb_id}'
    resp = requests.get(url)
    if resp.status_code == 200:
        data = resp.json()
        for entity in data.get('nonpolymer_entities', []):
            chem_comp = entity.get('chem_comp', {})
            all_results.append({
                'pdb_id': pdb_id,
                'entity_id': chem_comp.get('id', ''),
                'entity_name': chem_comp.get('name', ''),
                'entity_type': chem_comp.get('type', '')
            })
pd.DataFrame(all_results).to_csv('batch_als_pdb_entities.csv', index=False)


3.2.3 3. Find Known Ligands for a Target in ChEMBL
from chembl_webresource_client.new_client import new_client
target = new_client.target
activity = new_client.activity
acc = 'P00441'  # UniProt for SOD1
targets = list(target.filter(target_components__accession=acc))
chembl_id = targets[0]['target_chembl_id']
acts = activity.filter(target_chembl_id=chembl_id, standard_type='IC50')
for a in list(acts)[:5]:
    print(a.get('molecule_chembl_id'), a.get('standard_value'))

title: 10  Chapter 6: Graph Neural Networks
text:
10.2 Key Code Snippets

10.2.1 1. Construct a Molecular Graph with RDKit and NetworkX
from rdkit import Chem
import networkx as nx
smiles = "CCO"
mol = Chem.MolFromSmiles(smiles)
G = nx.Graph()
for atom in mol.GetAtoms():
    G.add_node(atom.GetIdx(), label=atom.GetSymbol())
for bond in mol.GetBonds():
    G.add_edge(bond.GetBeginAtomIdx(), bond.GetEndAtomIdx(), type=bond.GetBondType())


10.2.2 2. Simple GNN Layer with PyTorch Geometric
from torch_geometric.nn import GCNConv
import torch
conv = GCNConv(in_channels=10, out_channels=16)
x = torch.randn((num_nodes, 10))
edge_index = ...  # edge list as tensor
out = conv(x, edge_index)

title: 11  Chapter 7: Bioactivity Prediction
text:
11.2 Key Code Snippets

11.2.1 1. Load Bioactivity Data from ChEMBL
from chembl_webresource_client.new_client import new_client
activity = new_client.activity
acts = activity.filter(target_chembl_id="CHEMBL25", standard_type="IC50")
for a in list(acts)[:5]:
    print(a['molecule_chembl_id'], a['standard_value'])


11.2.2 2. Train a Classifier for Bioactivity
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
X = ...  # feature matrix
y = ...  # binary activity labels
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2)
clf = RandomForestClassifier()
clf.fit(X_train, y_train)
print("Accuracy:", clf.score(X_test, y_test))

title: 12  Chapter 8: ADMET Prediction
text:
12.2 Key Code Snippets

12.2.1 1. Calculate ADMET Descriptors with RDKit
from rdkit import Chem
from rdkit.Chem import Crippen, Descriptors
smiles = "CCO"
mol = Chem.MolFromSmiles(smiles)
logp = Crippen.MolLogP(mol)
mw = Descriptors.MolWt(mol)
print(f"LogP: {logp}, MW: {mw}")


12.2.2 2. Predict Toxicity with a Pretrained Model (Example)
# Example only: replace with actual model
import joblib
model = joblib.load('tox_model.pkl')
X = ...  # feature matrix
tox_pred = model.predict(X)

title: 13  Chapter 9: Molecular Generation

13.2 Key Code Snippets

13.2.1 1. Generate Molecules with a SMILES RNN (Example)
# Example only: replace with actual model
import torch
model = ...  # pretrained RNN
z = torch.randn(1, latent_dim)
smiles = model.sample(z)
print(smiles)


13.2.2 2. Evaluate Validity of Generated SMILES
from rdkit import Chem
smiles_list = ["CCO", "invalid_smiles"]
for s in smiles_list:
    mol = Chem.MolFromSmiles(s)
    print(f"{s}: {'valid' if mol else 'invalid'}")
